[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: check_network()] [Input Validation] Can an attacker bypass network validation by providing a chain_id string with leading/trailing whitespace that gets trimmed and matches after parsing, potentially allowing cross-chain replay attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: check_network()] [Chain ID Confusion] Does the trim() operation on network identifier allow attackers to inject whitespace-padded chain IDs that pass validation but cause downstream parsing inconsistencies? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: check_network()] [Error Handling] Can an attacker cause denial of service by sending malformed chain_id strings that trigger expensive parsing errors repeatedly? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: check_network()] [Logic Bypass] Does the function properly handle the case where blockchain name is 'aptos' but the ChainId parsing fails, or could this lead to inconsistent error states? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: check_network()] [Type Confusion] Can numeric chain IDs be confused with named chain IDs (testnet/mainnet) in the string parsing, allowing cross-network transaction submission? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: handle_request()] [Async Race Condition] Can concurrent requests trigger race conditions in the async handler where RosettaContext state is cloned but internal Arc references are shared unsafely? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: handle_request()] [Error Information Leak] Does the debug logging of full responses and errors at line 80-87 leak sensitive information like private keys, signatures, or internal state that could aid attackers? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: handle_request()] [Status Code Manipulation] Can an attacker craft ApiError variants that return incorrect HTTP status codes, potentially bypassing client-side error handling and security checks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: handle_request()] [Future Pinning] Does the Box::pin() operation at line 96 properly handle panics in the inner future, or can unhandled panics corrupt shared state? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: handle_request()] [Clone Safety] Is the RosettaContext clone operation at line 52 safe when rest_client and block_cache are Arc-wrapped, or can this lead to unexpected shared mutable state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: get_account()] [Race Condition] Can concurrent account queries during state transitions return inconsistent account data if the underlying rest_client doesn't properly synchronize reads? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: get_account()] [Information Disclosure] Does converting all rest_client errors to AccountNotFound hide critical errors like network failures, potentially masking attacks in progress? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: get_account()] [Address Validation] Is the AccountAddress parameter validated before the REST call, or can specially crafted addresses cause the REST client to behave unexpectedly? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: get_timestamp()] [Integer Overflow] Can an attacker provide a u64::MAX timestamp_usecs value that causes overflow during the division by 1000 at line 114, leading to incorrect timestamp calculations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: get_timestamp()] [Time Manipulation] Does the Y2K_MS clamping at line 117-119 allow attackers to submit blocks with pre-2000 timestamps that get normalized, enabling timestamp-based attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: get_timestamp()] [Timestamp Consistency] Can the microsecond to millisecond conversion lose precision in ways that cause transaction ordering issues or enable timestamp-based replay attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: get_timestamp()] [Boundary Condition] Does the comparison at line 117 handle the exact Y2K_MS boundary correctly, or could edge cases at exactly 946713600000 microseconds cause inconsistencies? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: strip_hex_prefix()] [Input Validation] Can attackers provide malformed hex strings without 0x prefix that pass through but cause parsing errors downstream, leading to transaction construction failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: strip_hex_prefix()] [Case Sensitivity] Does the function handle mixed-case hex strings correctly, or can uppercase/lowercase variations bypass validation checks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: to_hex_lower()] [Type Confusion] Can non-standard types implementing LowerHex be passed to produce unexpected hex outputs that break downstream parsing? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: encode_bcs()] [Serialization Attack] Can an attacker craft malicious structs with circular references or excessive nesting that cause BCS encoding to consume excessive memory or time? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: encode_bcs()] [Error Handling] Does bcs::to_bytes properly handle all error cases, or can deserialization errors be triggered that leak internal state information? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rosetta/src/common.rs] [Function: decode_bcs()] [Deserialization Attack] Can maliciously crafted BCS payloads exploit vulnerabilities in bcs::from_bytes to achieve arbitrary code execution or memory corruption? (Critical)
